title: Second Law of Thermodynamics (Entropy)
formal_statement: In an isolated system, the total entropy (disorder) never decreases over time: ΔS ≥ 0. For reversible processes ΔS = 0, for irreversible processes ΔS > 0.
plain_language: Isolated systems naturally evolve toward states of higher disorder (entropy). You cannot extract useful work perpetually from a system without an external energy source or gradient.
assumptions_scope: System is isolated (no energy or matter exchange with environment)
Macroscopic time scales (not brief quantum fluctuations)
Statistical interpretation (valid for large number of particles)
Classical or quantum statistical mechanics applies
typical_traps: Designing perpetual motion machines of the second kind
Ignoring that local entropy decreases require global entropy increases
Assuming perfect efficiency in energy conversion is achievable
Not recognizing that ordered structures (life, computers) require entropy export

escape_hatches.description: Use open systems with external energy gradients
examples: Solar energy input to Earth (drives life and weather)
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Requires external energy source; system no longer isolated; entropy increases in larger system

examples: Carnot efficiency limit for heat engines: η ≤ 1 - Tc/Th
Accept energy dissipation as waste heat
Design for maximum achievable efficiency, not perfection
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Cannot reach 100% efficiency; some energy always degraded to heat

escape_hatches.description: Exploit local entropy reduction with global increase
examples: Biological systems (decrease entropy locally via metabolism)
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Total entropy of universe still increases; requires energy input

test_or_check: Check if the claim requires perpetual work extraction from isolated system, or perfect efficiency in energy conversion, or entropy decrease without compensating increase elsewhere. If yes, flag as conflicting with Second Law.
references: Carnot, S. (1824). Réflexions sur la puissance motrice du feu et sur les machines propres à développer cette puissance. Bachelier.
Clausius, R. (1865). Über verschiedene für die Anwendung bequeme Formen der Hauptgleichungen der mechanischen Wärmetheorie. Annalen der Physik, 201(7), 353-400.
notes: The Second Law is one of the most fundamental principles in physics, with implications spanning thermodynamics, information theory, cosmology, and the arrow of time. It has never been violated in any observed physical process.
